items.title: Herndon students win culinary challenge with nutritious creamy gnocchi soup
items.summary: Herndon High School students cooked up a creamy gnocchi soup that earned them the top spot at the Real Food for Kids Culinary Challenge. News4’s Molette Green reports.

items.title: Volunteers paint inspirational messages on rocks for DC youth emergency shelter
items.summary: Love rocks! It’s Volunteer Month and Comcast is teaming up with Sasha Bruce Youthworks, D.C.’s only emergency shelter for kids, to beautify their space with inspirational rocks, pillows and more. News4’s Molette Green reports live from the NBC4 station.

items.title: DC nonprofit hosts ‘Craft for a Cause' to make costumes for kids
items.summary: D.C. nonprofit “Only Make Believe” will host a volunteer event called “Craft for a Cause” to make costumes for kids with disabilities on Saturday. News4’s Molette Green reports.

items.title: ‘Paint It Forward': Painters, volunteers help Gaithersburg supportive housing residents
items.summary: Neighbors in Gaithersburg are coming together to end homelessness. News4’s Molette Green reports on the “paint it forward” event helping more than three dozen families who receive housing support.

items.title: 2 Bowie brothers host community cold plunges in backyard in honor of sobriety
items.summary: The Paradise Brothers, Jeremiah and Zach McBride, started cold plunges to maintain their sobriety. The activity since has created a community in their backyard. News4’s Molette Green reports.

items.title: Arlington woman shares young-onset Parkinson's journey and advocates for research
items.summary: Allison “Allie” Signorelli started sharing her journey with young-onset Parkinson’s on Instagram to create a community with others. Since then, she has joined research studies and teamed up with advocates to spread awareness. News4’s Molette Green reports.

items.title: Emerging women engineers from Wheaton High School win medal at Dubai competition
items.summary: Wheaton High School’s Society of Women Engineers took home a bronze medal at the 2025 UAE Electric Vehicle Grand Prix in Dubai. Some students explain their role in building electric cars from scratch. News4’s Molette Green reports.

items.title: ‘Talk about it': National Epilepsy Walk in DC pushes for federal research funding
items.summary: The National Epilepsy Walk in Washington, D.C., is happening this weekend in hopes of raising awareness and getting more funding for research into the condition. News4’s Molette Green reports. For more information, visit cureepilepsy.org.

items.title: NBC4 & T44 Local Impact Grant program applications are open for 2025
items.summary: More than $227,000 unrestricted funding is available to local nonprofits across D.C., Maryland and Virginia through the NBC4 and Telemundo 44 Local Impact Grants. News4’s Molette Green looks back to the 2024 winners.

items.title: Forum aims to expose sex trafficking in Prince George's County
items.summary: Black women and girls are more vulnerable to sex trafficking than other groups. As shocking as that sounds, a lot of people are unaware. But a forum in Prince George’s County called “Human and Sex Trafficking Exposed” is putting the issue front and center. News4’s Molette Green reports.

items.title: Black Marriage Week retreat helps couples build healthy bonds, emotional intimacy
items.summary: Black Marriage Week is a retreat-style conference to help married couples through hardships through conversation, trust and workshops. The event is facilitated by the Relationship Boosters, a group of licensed therapists. News4’s Molette Green reports.

items.title: Calvert County students create original monuments to honor women in STEM
items.summary: After visiting the National Mall, Calvert County students found that monuments honoring women were rare. Mount Harmony Elementary School students drew monuments honoring women in the past and current women in STEM. News4’s Molette Green reports.

items.title: Brother-sister duo plans book drives to encourage kids to read
items.summary: A brother and sister from Bethesda, Maryland help run “The Lemonade Society” to encourage their peers to read through book club meetings and book drives. News4’s Molette Green reports. For more information, visit: www.liteararysociety.org/the-lemonade-society

items.title: Nonprofit helps young people with speech disorders grow confidence
items.summary: SAY, also known as The Stuttering Association for the Young, helps young people with speech disorders gain confidence through speech therapy and engaging activities in performing arts. News4’s Molette Green talks about the founder about why he started the program and its inaugural fundraising gala.
